title: About
text:
If you’re looking for a bio, please use the text below. If you are looking for pictures, please use

Professional headshot with dark background
Professional headshot with light background
Casual picture



Rahul is the CEO of the FOSS United Foundation, which works to support and promote the Free & Open Source Software (FOSS) ecosystem in India. He has been contributing to the FOSS ecosystem for more than eight years, both through code contributions and by giving talks about various FOSS technologies.



Rahul is the CEO of the FOSS United Foundation, the Head of Software at Softcircuits Labs, and an Advisor to the Saryan Vigyan Foundation.
He pursued B.S. & M.S. in Physics from the Indian Institute of Technology Madras, and got interested in Programming and Free & Open Source Software (FOSS) when creating simulations for toy physics models. After graduation, he lucked into a Scientific Software Developer role at Enthought, where he built software to solve Scientific and Engineering problems. While at Enthought, he got to work from Pune, India, Chennai, India, Austin, Texas, USA, and Cambridge, UK over eight interesting years. He started contributing to FOSS projects in the Scientific Python ecosystem while at Enthought, eventually becoming a maintainer for a few FOSS projects created at Enthought.
He got lucky again when he received a Scholarship from the FOSS United Foundation to pursue the Graduate Certificate in Public Policy (Tech & Policy) course by the Takshashila Institution. He started volunteering with the FOSS United Foundation afterwards, speaking at various FOSS United events, helping organize IndiaFOSS 2023, and organizing HydFOSS 2023. He eventually joined FOSS United full-time in May 2024 and has been with the Foundation ever since.
He loves to teach and has given talks and workshops on various topics like Python Programming, FOSS, FOSS Policy, and Tech Policy in general.
His wife, Dr. Preeti Saryan, co-founded the Saryan Vigyan Foundation. He and his wife argue about two things - how to run an organization and how to raise their son, Luffy.

title: Talks
text:
I strongly believe that if I can’t explain a concept to a layperson, I haven’t really understood the concept. I’ve been engaged in public speaking since 2009, when I was part of the Astronomy Club at my almamater. For more than 15 years, I’ve tried to explain concepts in Astronomy, Astrophysics, Cosmology, Physics, Python, Scientific Computing, Software development and Software Architecture, Free & Open Source Software, Digital Commons, Public Policy/Tech Policy, and more. What follows is a non-exhaustive list, in reverse chronological order.



[September] Conducted a workshop on the Frappe Framework at PyCon India 2025
[August] Introduced the Free & Open Source Software ecosystem to students and faculty at T.S.Negi Government College, Reckong Peo, Himachal Pradesh
[August] Participated in a panel discussion on “Openness & AI” as part of a series of events on “Openness and Access for All”





[August] Talked about FOSS & Digital Commons on the All Things Policy podcast by the Takshashila Institution
[August] Internal AMA with the Product, Engineering, Design, and Data Science teams at Wadhwani AI about anything Free & Open Source Software
[July] Moderated a panel discussion on FOSS & the Education Sector at the Roundtable on FOSS in India event
[July] Participated in a panel discussion on the Strategic importance of FOSS for India at Roundtable on FOSS in India event
[July] Participated in a panel discussion on “Ensuring Open-Source and Community-driven DPI” as part of the DPI in Conversation series of events organized by SFLC.in
[July] Participated in a panel discussion on Downstreaming Responsible AI in India by the Aapti Institute
[June] Talked about “Open Source & AI” as part of a series of Faculty Development Program sessions at the AI & ML department, Symbiosis Institute of Technology Pune
[June] Participated in a panel discussion on “Open Source trends & challenges for the community in India”, organized as part of a series of events during Open Source Week by SFLC.in
[March] Invited to FOSSMeet 2025, where I talked about FOSS Policy 101
[March] Talked about “FOSS & Tech Policy in India” at devconf.in 2025





[February] Participated in a panel discussion on “The Power of Open Source and Collaborative Technology for Social Change” as part of Dasra Philanthropy Week 2025
[January] Moderated a panel discussion on Free & Open Source Software for the not-for-profit ecosystem at the OASIS Spark event





[December] Participated in the “Sustaining DPGs: Open-source, community-led development & maintenance” panel discussion at DPG Dialogues 2024





[October] Talked to Kalvium students about FOSS in Engineering Education, as part of their Hacktober series of talks
[October] Talked about FOSS & Progress to the Fellows at Citizens for Public Leadership

title: Poruri Sai Rahul
text:
FOSS / Science / Policy / India



I’m a Physics student-turned software developer, currently cosplaying as the CEO of the FOSS United Foundation. I spend most of my time thinking about the incentives that enable or hinder the adoption of Free & Open Source Software in India. Thanks to my day job, I get to talk to interesting folks from the industry, academia, and the civil society about FOSS and technology in general. If you’re trying to understand the Indian FOSS ecosystem, or if you’re trying to adopt or create FOSS in India, I’m happy to chat.
FOSS communities have existed in India for many years, and FOSS United is one of the newer communities. Established in 2020, the FOSS United Foundation aims to promote and support the FOSS ecosystem in India. If you’re interested in participating in the FOSS United Community, please checkout out our discourse forum, participate in our telegram group, or drop by one of our events.
I currently (Oct, 2025) live in Hyderabad, Telangana, India and I participate in a few communities - FOSS United Hyderabad, FOSS x Policy reading group, and SciPy India.
